I have been given the task at my workplace to be the junit guru for
our dev=
elopment team. While we have the basic shell in place to make
use of it, no=
 one has, and our manager wants to start. 

I downloaded the jUnitDoclet co=
de so that we could generate a junit
shell for our whole application, and s=
lowly start filling it out, and
am encountering a few difficulties. I am tr=
ying to getting running in
Eclipse. I have set it up as an external tool as=
 per the instructions.
I have had to do a few fiddly fixes due to spaces be=
ing in used here
and there in our path (source code is in a "Java Source" d=
irectory),
but that's fine, I figured that all out.

What I am having troub=
le with, is the classpath. I know I can pass a
classpath as a parameter to =
the run_junitdoclet.bat file, though I am
having difficulty making even tha=
t work. What I would really like, is
to have it run, using the classpath of=
 my specific project. I would
prefer it being project relevant so that the =
same logic will work on
any project. The problem is that as it runs, it cre=
ates a whole pile
of compiler errors indicating that x reference or y packa=
ge doesn't
exist. Now sometimes, despite that, it will still create the tes=
t
class, so ultimately, it seems to work (if you just ignore over a
hundred=
 error mesages). Other times, it seems there are too many
errors for the te=
st class to get written. This really prevents me from
just trying to build =
every class in our application (way to many to go
one by one).

So...can I =
get it to use the project classpath, if not, what am I
missing from passing=
 in classpath as a parameter. I added 

".\Web Content\WEB-INF\lib"

as a c=
lasspath parameter, which does help, as I don't seem to get any
errors for =
any jar files that fall into this area, and this is
*always* a relevant are=
a, but we do reference other jar files as well,
in some cases other project=
s, and in some cases external directories
entirely (like Tomcat's common\li=
b folder). I tried extending it to..

".\Web Content\WEB-INF\lib;C:\Tomcat =
5.0\common\lib\"

and I get an error

"Content\WEB-INF\lib was unexpected a=
t this time."

so I am getting a little puzzled, and I just realized how lo=
ng this
message is, thanks for geting this far.
